\chapter{Algorithmic Differentiation as Sensitivity Analysis in Cloud Microphysics}
\label{\detokenize{index:algorithmic-differentiation-as-sensitivity-analysis-in-cloud-microphysics}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Microphysical processes in convective clouds have an impact on radiation in climate models, precipitation and dynamical features. These processes are usually parameterized, i.e. in numerical weather prediction (NWP) models, due to the small scale in which those processes operate and the lack of understanding of some. Understanding the impact of uncertainties in parametrization to uncertainty in cloud responses is crucial for tuning such models. In addition, parameter values can depend on discretization details such as the grid interval, time resolution and other choices made by modeling physical processes. Typical sensitivity analysis investigate few model parameters selected by experts and perturb those based on (joint) proposal distributions that may be refined by experts. In this paper we propose algorithmic differentiation (AD) as a tool to detect the magnitude and time step at which a model state parameter is sensitive to any of hundreds of model parameters. We implement a two\sphinxhyphen{}moment scheme and identify the 20 most important parameters to each hydrometeor and validate those parameters by comparing perturbed ensembles and the resulting divergence with predicted deviations. Finally, we use the output of AD for detecting the time step at which perturbing a parameter is necessary with a random forest and a precision and recall of about 75\% for each model parameter and hydrometeor.

\sphinxAtStartPar
This repository consists of an implementation of a two\sphinxhyphen{}moment scheme (similar to {[}ICON{]}(\sphinxurl{https://www.dwd.de/EN/research/weatherforecasting/num\_modelling/01\_num\_weather\_prediction\_modells/icon\_description.html})) with {[}AD using CoDiPack{]}(\sphinxurl{https://github.com/scicompkl/codipack}) where environment and intial variables are read from {[}NetCDF{]}(\sphinxurl{https://www.unidata.ucar.edu/software/netcdf/}) files. Python scripts are used for post\sphinxhyphen{}processing and data analysis. For the C++ code we follow the
{[}doxygen standard{]}(\sphinxurl{http://www.doxygen.nl/manual/docblocks.html}). We recommend an {[}anaconda{]}(\sphinxurl{https://www.anaconda.com/}) environment for which you may
use \sphinxtitleref{requirements\_conda.txt}. Either way, \sphinxtitleref{requirements\_pip.txt} with pip is needed
as well to create a documentation.

\sphinxAtStartPar
We also provide a docker image \sphinxtitleref{mahieronymus/ad\_sensitivity:2.0} with all necessary prerequisites installed.

\section{Compiling code}
\label{\detokenize{index:compiling-code}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
In order to compile the code, create a folder \sphinxtitleref{build} and in this folder type
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\textasciigrave{}
cmake .. \sphinxhyphen{}DCMAKE\_BUILD\_TYPE=release \sphinxhyphen{}DTRUSTED\_DATA:BOOL=ON \sphinxhyphen{}DTARGET=simulation
make \sphinxhyphen{}j 6
\textasciigrave{}}}
With the option \sphinxtitleref{TRUSTED\_DATA} the program just stops simulations for every trajectory with more than 10
consecutive NaNs for every other input column. Without this option, the program
assumes the dataset is broken and terminates directly, giving information which
trajectory and time index starts with consecutive NaNs.

\sphinxAtStartPar
You may change the number for \sphinxtitleref{make} to the number of cores available.
In case the CMake does not find a specific library, you can specify them like this:
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\textasciigrave{}
cmake .. \sphinxhyphen{}DNETCDF\_INCLUDE\_DIR=\textless{}path/to/netcdf/include/\textgreater{} \sphinxhyphen{}DCODIPACK\_INCLUDEDIR=\textless{}path/to/codipack/include/\textgreater{} \sphinxhyphen{}DHDF5\_DIR=\textless{}path/to/hdf5/\textgreater{} \sphinxhyphen{}DCMAKE\_BUILD\_TYPE=release
\textasciigrave{}}}
You may change the target for timing the microphysics with \sphinxtitleref{\sphinxhyphen{}DTARGET=timing} if you wish to check the penalty cost of executing AD at every time step for varying amounts of model state variables and model parameters.

\sphinxAtStartPar
You can add \sphinxtitleref{\sphinxhyphen{}DCOMPRESS\_OUTPUT:BOOL=ON} to write compressed output with zlib. You need for this HDF5 v1.10.2 or higher. Compression is only supported for sensitivity analysis but not for ensemble simulations at the moment.


\section{Running a simulation}
\label{\detokenize{index:running-a-simulation}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
We provide three bash scripts to execute the code in \sphinxtitleref{exe\_scripts}. You may change the value of variable
\sphinxtitleref{NTASKS} to the number of cores available in the script if available.
\sphinxtitleref{perturbed\_ensembles.sh} generates the data for estimating the correlation between AD\sphinxhyphen{}estimated deviations and
ensemble\sphinxhyphen{}estimated deviations. The data is stored under \sphinxtitleref{data/vladiana\_ensembles/}.
It runs perturbed ensembles every 30 minutes with a single parameter being perturbed for each member.
For postprocessing, you have to execute the following command in \sphinxtitleref{scripts}:
{\color{red}\bfseries{}\textasciigrave{}\textasciigrave{}}\textasciigrave{}
python segment\_identifier.py 
\begin{quote}

\sphinxAtStartPar
\textendash{}data\_path ../data/vladiana\_ensembles/ \textendash{}verbosity 3 \textendash{}store\_appended\_data ../data/vladiana\_ensembles\_postprocess/predictions.nc \textendash{}only\_append
\end{quote}

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\textasciigrave{}
You may now delete the files in \textasciigrave{}data/vladiana\_ensembles/\textasciigrave{} since we do not need them anymore. You can visualize the results, for example a comparison of the simulated
rain mass density with the gradients:
\textasciigrave{}}}
python plot\_mse.py 
\begin{quote}

\sphinxAtStartPar
\textendash{}data\_path ../data/vladiana\_ensembles\_postprocess/predictions.nc \textendash{}backend matplotlib \textendash{}store\_path ../pics/qr\_AD\_example \textendash{}xlabel TimeAfterAscentBegins{[}min{]} \textendash{}ylabel “” \textendash{}title ResultsofADOverTime \textendash{}width 1600 \textendash{}height 900 \textendash{}plot\_variant time\_plot \textendash{}traj 1 \textendash{}twinlabel PredictedDeviation \textendash{}n\_model\_params 5 \textendash{}max\_time 7500 \textendash{}out\_parameter QR
\end{quote}

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\textasciigrave{}
Or for snow:
\textasciigrave{}}}
python plot\_mse.py 
\begin{quote}

\sphinxAtStartPar
\textendash{}data\_path ../data/vladiana\_ensembles\_postprocess/predictions.nc \textendash{}backend matplotlib \textendash{}store\_path ../pics/qs\_AD\_example \textendash{}xlabel TimeAfterAscentBegins{[}min{]} \textendash{}ylabel “” \textendash{}title ResultsofADOverTime \textendash{}width 1600 \textendash{}height 900 \textendash{}plot\_variant time\_plot \textendash{}traj 1 \textendash{}twinlabel PredictedDeviation \textendash{}n\_model\_params 1 \textendash{}max\_time 7500 \textendash{}min\_time 2500 \textendash{}out\_parameter QS
\end{quote}

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\textasciigrave{}
Plots that show the correlation between AD\sphinxhyphen{}estimated and ensemble\sphinxhyphen{}estimated
devation for all model state variables at once can be generated with:
\textasciigrave{}}}
python plot\_mse.py 
\begin{quote}

\sphinxAtStartPar
\textendash{}data\_path ../data/vladiana\_ensembles\_postprocess/predictions.nc \textendash{}add\_zero\_sens \textendash{}plot\_types \textendash{}backend bokeh \textendash{}store\_path ../pics/correlation \textendash{}xlabel AD\sphinxhyphen{}EstimatedLogMSD \textendash{}ylabel Ensemble\sphinxhyphen{}EstimatedLogMSD \textendash{}title EnsemblevsADEstimation \textendash{}width 900 \textendash{}height 900 \textendash{}plot\_variant correlation \textendash{}out\_parameter all\_at\_once
\end{quote}

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\textasciigrave{}
or only for water vapor mass density:
\textasciigrave{}}}
python plot\_mse.py 
\begin{quote}

\sphinxAtStartPar
\textendash{}data\_path /data/project/wcb/netcdf/vladiana\_keyparams\_errors/predictions.nc \textendash{}add\_zero\_sens \textendash{}plot\_types \textendash{}backend bokeh \textendash{}store\_path ../pics/correlation \textendash{}confidence 0.90 \textendash{}xlabel AD\sphinxhyphen{}EstimatedLogMSD \textendash{}ylabel Ensemble\sphinxhyphen{}EstimatedLogMSD \textendash{}title Ens.vsADEst. \textendash{}width 900 \textendash{}height 900 \textendash{}plot\_variant correlation \textendash{}out\_parameter QV

\section{Adding New Physics}
\label{\detokenize{index:adding-new-physics}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Any user\sphinxhyphen{}defined functions and processes are under \sphinxtitleref{include/microphysics/user\_functions.h}.
Just add your microphysics there to solve the ODE. We use one function to solve the
right\sphinxhyphen{}hand side of the ODE, called \sphinxtitleref{RHS\_SB}, that calls all necessary functions
to process the microphysics. One may create a similar function that uses different
microphysics.
The datatype \sphinxtitleref{codi::RealReverse} is from CODIPACK and can mostly
be handled like \sphinxtitleref{double}. Next you may open \sphinxtitleref{include/microphysics/rk4.h} and either copy \sphinxtitleref{RK4\_step(..)} as
\sphinxtitleref{my\_RK4\_step(..)} and make it use your function,
or simply add pragmas around the function calls like that:
{\color{red}\bfseries{}\textasciigrave{}\textasciigrave{}}{\color{red}\bfseries{}\textasciigrave{}}C++
\#ifdef MY\_MICROPHYSICS
\begin{quote}

\sphinxAtStartPar
my\_physics(k, yold, ref, cc, nc);
\end{quote}
\begin{description}
\item[{\#else}] \leavevmode
\sphinxAtStartPar
RHS(k, yold, ref, cc, nc);

\end{description}

\sphinxAtStartPar
\#endif
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\textasciigrave{}
where \textasciigrave{}MY\_MICROPHYSICS\textasciigrave{} is a name you give to make use of your own function during
compile time (set \textasciigrave{}TIMESTEPPER=\sphinxhyphen{}DMY\_MICROPHYSICS\textasciigrave{} in CMake).
Note, you only need to create your own \textasciigrave{}RK4\_step(..)\textasciigrave{} if the given arguments are
not sufficient for your own needs! \textbackslash{}
At last, go to \textasciigrave{}src/microphysics/trajectories.cpp\textasciigrave{} and search for:
\textasciigrave{}}}
//////////////// Add any different scheme and model here
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\textasciigrave{}
Add pragmas as before to make use of your timestepper method. If you already
added pragmas in \textasciigrave{}rk4.h\textasciigrave{}, it is sufficient to change:
\textasciigrave{}\textasciigrave{}\textasciigrave{}C++
\#elif defined(RK4ICE)
\textasciigrave{}}}
to
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\textasciigrave{}C++
\#elif defined(RK4) || defined(MY\_MICROPHYSICS)
\textasciigrave{}}}
Otherwise you need to add additional lines of code, such as:
{\color{red}\bfseries{}\textasciigrave{}\textasciigrave{}}{\color{red}\bfseries{}\textasciigrave{}}C++
\#elif defined(MY\_MICROPHYSICS)
\begin{quote}

\sphinxAtStartPar
my\_RK4\_step(..);
\end{quote}

\sphinxAtStartPar
\#elif defined(RK4ICE)
{\color{red}\bfseries{}\textasciigrave{}\textasciigrave{}}\textasciigrave{}
If you are using new model parameters, then you have to add them to the enum
\sphinxtitleref{Cons\_idx} or if you need model parameters specific to certain
hydrometeors, you have to add them to the enum \sphinxtitleref{Particle\_cons\_idx} located
in \sphinxtitleref{include/microphysics/constants.h}. The same file has to maps \sphinxtitleref{table\_particle\_param}
for hydrometeor specific parameters and \sphinxtitleref{table\_param} for all other parameters
to map the parameters to a name used for the output.
If your parameters depend on others, you may add such functions to the class
\sphinxtitleref{model\_constants\_t} which should be called by \sphinxtitleref{setup\_model\_constants(..)}.
To avoid any confusion, you might want to decorate your version with pragmas.

Compute a single step using the Runge\sphinxhyphen{}Kutta 4 method for the ODE \begin{equation*}
\begin{split} y' = \text{RHS}(y) \end{split}
\end{equation*} with old system state yold and new system state ynew. It uses the 2 moment bulk scheme from 10.1175/JAS3980 with ice.

\sphinxAtStartPar

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar

\sphinxAtStartPar
Sedimentation after Seifert and Beheng (2006). This function processes rain, snow, ice, hail and graupel sedimentation at once. The main difference in sedi\_icon\_core to ICON and COSMO here is that we do not approximate the fall velocity based on the cell above the current one. We simply don’t have that information in a simulation along trajectories.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Furthermore the improved scheme in sedi\_icon\_box\_core originally uses the information of each flux in all boxes above the current one. This information isn’t available as well.

\sphinxAtStartPar
In short: Only sedimentation from the current box is calculated here. Sedimentation that may come from further above is not used here.

\sphinxAtStartPar
See \sphinxurl{http://www.cosmo-model.org/content/model/documentation/core/docu\_sedi\_twomom.pdf} for more details.

\sphinxAtStartPar
@params T\_prime Temperature {[}K{]} @params S Saturation @params qc\_prime Cloud water mixing ratio @params qr\_prime Rain mixing ratio @params Nr Number of rain droplets @params qs\_prime Snowflakes mixing ratio @params Ns Number of snowflakes @params qi\_prime Ice crystal mixing ratio @params Ni Number of ice crystals @params qh\_prime Hail mixing ratio @params Nh Number of hail particles @params qg\_prime Graupel mixing ratio @params Ng Number of graupel particles @params p\_prime Pressure {[}Pa{]} @params res Vector to store the changes @params cc Model constants 

\end{fulllineitems}

\subsection{Example Results for a Single Trajectory}
\label{\detokenize{results/traj0:example-results-for-a-single-trajectory}}\label{\detokenize{results/traj0::doc}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
If we use the data from \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{2mom\_wcb/traj\_t000000\_p001.nc\_wcb}} for the
trajectory with index 0 and \(0 \text{s} \leq t \leq 187920 \text{s}\), we get data from within
a region that satisfies the WCB\sphinxhyphen{}criterion (see Section 2.3 of {\hyperref[\detokenize{results/traj0:oertel2019}]{\sphinxcrossref{Oertel2019}}}).
One can execute the simulation with the following command, executed at the
root folder of the repository:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
build/apps/src/microphysics/./trajectories \PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}}
\PYGZhy{}a \PYG{l+m}{3} \PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}}
\PYGZhy{}t \PYG{l+m}{0} \PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}}
\PYGZhy{}s \PYG{l+m}{1} \PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}}
\PYGZhy{}f \PYG{l+m}{187920} \PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}}
\PYGZhy{}d \PYG{l+m}{0}.01 \PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}}
\PYGZhy{}i \PYG{l+m}{250} \PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}}
\PYGZhy{}b \PYG{l+m}{1}.0 \PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}}
\PYGZhy{}o data/wcb\PYGZus{}sim \PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}}
\PYGZhy{}l 2mom\PYGZus{}wcb/traj\PYGZus{}t000000\PYGZus{}p001.nc\PYGZus{}wcb \PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}}
\PYGZhy{}r \PYG{l+m}{0}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
See the section on {\color{red}\bfseries{}Executing\_} for a description of these commands. In short,
we are resetting variables such as temperature, saturation, pressure and
ascent every \(20 \text{s}\), the timestep size of the netCDF file. Those variables,
except for ascent, are not fixed while calculating the microphysics.
The timestep for the microphysics is \(0.01 \text{s}\). We capture the results and
derivatives every 250 timesteps (\(=2.5 \text{s}\)).
We can plot all the following plots with:


\subsubsection{Ice Mixing Ratio}
\label{\detokenize{results/traj0:ice-mixing-ratio}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Let’s take a look at the ice mixing ratio \(q_{\text{ice}}\):

\begin{figure}[htbp]
\centering

\noindent\sphinxincludegraphics{{traj_qi}.png}
\end{figure}

\begin{figure}[htbp]
\centering

\noindent\sphinxincludegraphics{{sim_qi_tr0}.png}
\end{figure}

\begin{figure}[htbp]
\centering
\capstart

\noindent\sphinxincludegraphics{{sim_qi}.png}
\caption{Ice crystal mixing ratio for multiple trajectories.}\label{\detokenize{results/traj0:id1}}\end{figure}

\begin{figure}[htbp]
\centering
\capstart

\noindent\sphinxincludegraphics{{qi_1}.png}
\caption{Ice mixing ratio derivatives with the highest impact. The colored background
stands for timesteps where the WCB\sphinxhyphen{}criterion is satisfied.}\label{\detokenize{results/traj0:id2}}\end{figure}

\sphinxAtStartPar
We can see that the minimum size for ice particles has an impact of \(\mathcal{O}(10^{-11})\).

\begin{figure}[htbp]
\centering
\capstart

\noindent\sphinxincludegraphics{{qi_2}.png}
\caption{Ice mixing ratio derivatives with the second highest impact. The colored background
stands for timesteps where the WCB\sphinxhyphen{}criterion is satisfied.}\label{\detokenize{results/traj0:id3}}\end{figure}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The parameters with the second highest impact of \(\mathcal{O}(10^{-21})\)
have largely negative derivatives. \(z^{-1}\) is the inverse height size
of the air parcel, which is set to \(150 \text{m}\) for this simulation.
The minimum size of a cloud particle is present as well. \(\text{vel}_{b, \text{ice}}\)
is a parameter for the vertical velocity of ice particles:
\begin{equation*}
\begin{split}\text{vel}_i = a_{\text{vel}} \cdot x^{b_{\text{vel}}} \cdot \rho_{\text{ice}, v}\end{split}
\end{equation*}
\sphinxAtStartPar
where \(x\) is the particle (mean) mass in kg and \(a_{\text{vel}}\) is
another particle model constant. Those \(a_{\text{vel}}\) and \(b_{\text{vel}}\)
are defined for every particle type separately. This particular \(\text{vel}_{b, \text{ice}}\)
is used in the ice self collection (see {\hyperref[\detokenize{results/traj0:cotton1986}]{\sphinxcrossref{Cotton1986}}} or {\hyperref[\detokenize{results/traj0:straka1989}]{\sphinxcrossref{Straka1989}}} page 53 for
temperature dependency).
The collection of ice crystals after {\hyperref[\detokenize{results/traj0:seifert2006}]{\sphinxcrossref{Seifert2006}}} Eq. 62 is implemented as follows:
\begin{equation*}
\begin{split}\frac{\partial q_i}{\partial t} |_{\text{vel}_{b, \text{ice}}} =
- \frac{\pi}{4} e_{\text{coll}} \delta_{sc, q, \text{ice}}
    N_i q_i D_i^2 \sqrt{\theta_{sc, q, \text{ice}} \text{vel}_{\text{ice}}^2 + 2\cdot s_{\text{vel}, \text{ice}}^2}\end{split}
\end{equation*}
\sphinxAtStartPar
with \(e_{\text{coll}} = \text{min}(10^{0.035 \cdot T_c - 0.7}, 0.2)\)
the mean efficiency, \(T_c\) is the temperature in degree Celcius, \(N_i\)
is the amount of ice particles and \(q_i\) the ice mixing ratio.
\(\delta_{sc, q}\) and \(\theta_{sc, q}\) are dimensionless constants
(depending on chosen size distributions and velocity\sphinxhyphen{} and diameter\sphinxhyphen{}mass relations
of the colliding particles).
\(D_i\) is the mean particle diameter, which is calculated with the mean
particle mass \(x\) and some model constants:
\begin{equation*}
\begin{split}D_i = a_{\text{ice}, \text{geo}} \cdot x^{b_{\text{ice}, \text{geo}}}\end{split}
\end{equation*}
\sphinxAtStartPar
\(s_{\text{vel}, i} = 0.2 \text{m}\text{s}^{-1}\) is the constant variance
of the particle velocity.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The parameter \(\lambda_{\text{ice}}\) and \(\text{vel}_{b, \text{ice}}\)
are used in the sedimentation process:
\begin{equation*}
\begin{split}\frac{\partial q_i}{\partial t } |_{\lambda_{\text{ice}}, \text{vel}_{b, \text{ice}}} =
- \rho_{\text{corr}} \cdot \alpha_{\text{ice}, q} \cdot \lambda_{\text{ice}}
\cdot x^{\text{vel}_{b, \text{ice}}} \cdot q_i \cdot z^{-1}\end{split}
\end{equation*}
\sphinxAtStartPar
where \(\rho_{\text{corr}} = ( \frac{\rho_{a}'}{\rho_0} )^{-\rho_{\text{vel}}}\) is
used for density correction.
The air density \(\rho_0\) is set to \(1.225\), the exponent \(\rho_{\text{vel}}\)
is set to \(0.4\). The density of dry air \(\rho_{a}'\) can be calculated
using pressure, \(p\) temperature \(T\), saturation \(S\) and
the gas constant for dry air \(R_a\) via
\begin{equation*}
\begin{split}\rho_{a}' = \frac{ p - S \cdot p_{S, v} }{R_a \cdot T}\end{split}
\end{equation*}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The saturation vapor pressure \(p_{S, v}\) can be calculated with {\hyperref[\detokenize{results/traj0:murphy2005}]{\sphinxcrossref{Murphy2005}}}.

\begin{figure}[htbp]
\centering
\capstart

\noindent\sphinxincludegraphics{{qi_3}.png}
\caption{Ice mixing ratio derivatives with the third highest impact. The colored background
stands for timesteps where the WCB\sphinxhyphen{}criterion is satisfied.}\label{\detokenize{results/traj0:id4}}\end{figure}

\sphinxAtStartPar
There are more derivatives with impact of \(\mathcal{O}(10^{-24})\).
The minimum size of graupel and snow particles come to have an effect.
The parameters \(\text{geo}_{a, \text{ice}}\) and \(\text{geo}_{b, \text{ice}}\)
are used in calculating the particle diameter and hence for ice and ice
collisions (see above), ice riming from cloud and rain particles, conversion from ice to
graupel, vapor deposition, particle collection with snow and graupel.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Formula for cloud riming rate with a particle x ({\hyperref[\detokenize{results/traj0:seifert2006}]{\sphinxcrossref{Seifert2006}}}):
\begin{equation*}
\begin{split}\begin{split}
\frac{\partial q_i}{\partial t} |_{\text{cloud riming}}
= \frac{\Pi}{4} \cdot e_{\text{coll}} \cdot N_x \cdot q_c \\
\cdot ( \delta_{q, aa, icr} \cdot D_x^2 + \delta_{q, ab, icr} \cdot D_x \cdot D_c
+ \delta_{q, bb, icr} \cdot D_c^2 ) \\
\cdot \sqrt{ \theta_{q, aa, icr} \cdot v_x^2
- \theta_{q, ab, icr} \cdot v_x \cdot v_c
+ \theta_{q, bb, icr} \cdot v_c^2 + s^2_{\text{vel}, \text{ice}} }
\end{split}\end{split}
\end{equation*}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The subscript “icr” stands for ice cloud riming model constants and \(v\)
is the particle velocity. The rain riming rate can be calculated in a similar
way with model constants used from “irr” (ice rain riming) and properties from
rain instead of cloud droplets.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The parameter \(\delta_{sc, \text{ice}}\) is part of ice ice collisions as above.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The parameter \(\text{ven}_{a, \text{ice}}\) is used in vapor deposition
({\hyperref[\detokenize{results/traj0:seifert2006}]{\sphinxcrossref{Seifert2006}}}, Section 3.3, Equations 37 and 38).
\begin{equation*}
\begin{split}Another formula, maybe I add that later.\end{split}
\end{equation*}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The parameters \(s_{c, \text{ice}}\) and \(f_{a, \text{ice}}\) are used in depositional
growth of ice particles (as above) and evaporation ({\hyperref[\detokenize{results/traj0:seifert2006}]{\sphinxcrossref{Seifert2006}}}, Equations 76, 77):

\begin{split}Another formula\end{split}
\end{equation*}

\pysigstopmultiline
\sphinxAtStartPar
A lookup table for the lower incomplete gamma function from ICON mo\_2mom\_mcrph\_util.f90 at incgfct\_lower\_lookupcreate: \begin{equation*}
\begin{split} \text{int}(0)(x) \exp(-t) t^{a-1} \text{d}t \end{split}
\end{equation*}

\sphinxAtStartPar
with constant a from x=0 to the 99.5\% value of the normalized incomplete gamma function. This 99.5 \% \sphinxhyphen{} value has been fitted with high accuracy as function of a in the range a in {[}0;20{]}, but can safely be applied also to higher values of a. (Fit created with the matlab\sphinxhyphen{}program “gamma\_unvoll\_lower\_lookup.m” by Ulrich Blahak, 2008/11/13).

\sphinxAtStartPar
The last value in the table corresponds to x = infinity, so that during the reconstruction of incgfct\sphinxhyphen{}values from the table, the x\sphinxhyphen{}value can safely be truncated at the maximum table x\sphinxhyphen{}value.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Compute a single step using the Runge\sphinxhyphen{}Kutta 4 method for the ODE \begin{equation*}
\begin{split} y' = \text{RHS}(y) \end{split}
\end{equation*} with old system state yold and new system state ynew. It uses the 2 moment bulk scheme from 10.1175/JAS3980 with ice.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\begin{description}
\item[{\sphinxstylestrong{Parameters}}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ynew}}: On out: new system state 

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{yold}}: Old system state 

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ref}}: Pointer to reference quantities to transform between units 

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{cc}}: Pointer to constants from the model 

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{fixed}}: If True: Do not change pressure, temperature and ascent (w) 

\end{itemize}

\end{description}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Sedimentation after Seifert and Beheng (2006). This function processes rain, snow, ice, hail and graupel sedimentation at once. The main difference in sedi\_icon\_core to ICON and COSMO here is that we do not approximate the fall velocity based on the cell above the current one. We simply don’t have that information in a simulation along trajectories.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Furthermore the improved scheme in sedi\_icon\_box\_core originally uses the information of each flux in all boxes above the current one. This information isn’t available as well.

\sphinxAtStartPar
In short: Only sedimentation from the current box is calculated here. Sedimentation that may come from further above is not used here.

\sphinxAtStartPar
See \sphinxurl{http://www.cosmo-model.org/content/model/documentation/core/docu\_sedi\_twomom.pdf} for more details.

\sphinxAtStartPar
@params T\_prime Temperature {[}K{]} @params S Saturation @params qc\_prime Cloud water mixing ratio @params qr\_prime Rain mixing ratio @params Nr Number of rain droplets @params qs\_prime Snowflakes mixing ratio @params Ns Number of snowflakes @params qi\_prime Ice crystal mixing ratio @params Ni Number of ice crystals @params qh\_prime Hail mixing ratio @params Nh Number of hail particles @params qg\_prime Graupel mixing ratio @params Ng Number of graupel particles @params p\_prime Pressure {[}Pa{]} @params res Vector to store the changes @params cc Model constants 

\end{fulllineitems}
